title: Tuesday, 13th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:06am

Morning, hello, hi. Welcome to Markets Live.

BE11:06am

It's been a long, arduous week. A week full of noise, confusion and political stramash, but somehow we've made it through to .... wait ....

BE11:06am

Tuesday? Bloody hell.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

So anyway, we have an inflation report. Have an inflation report.

BE11:07am

BE11:08am

There's some reaction here: https://www.ft.com...-aa41-e163f23e7b0e

11:08 am
BE11:08am

And a story here: https://www.ft.com...d1b36?tagToFollow=

BE11:09am

Neither of which link to the actual report, because whatever I dunno. https://www.ons.go...einflation/may2017

BE11:10am

Let me get some comment to say "things are getting more expensive that's probably not good news for consumer spending but consumer spending has remained robust because of a historically low saving rate and ...."

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Here's Citi.

BE11:11am

Surprise inflation jump in May – CPI inflation jumped from 2.7% YY in April to 2.9% YY in May (Consensus 2.7%, Citi 2.5%), with core inflation (ex food and energy) rising from 2.4% YY to 2.6% YY. The ONS’ headline inflation measure CPI-H, which the Treasury and the Bank of England have not adopted for inflation targeting so far, showed a rise in inflation from 2.6% YY in April to 2.7%. RPI inflation rose from 3.5% YY in April to 3.7% YY (Consensus 3.5%, Citi 3.3%).

BE11:11am

 What was in line with our expectations? –The different pattern of Easter holidays compared to 2016 showed up in lower air fares inflation, which subtracted 0.1pp from the headline inflation rate. Energy inflation edged lower (from 6.9% YY in April to 6.1% YY in May) and food inflation edged up 0.1pp to 1.4% YY in May. These trends were in line with our expectation and should have triggered lower inflation.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

 What was not in line? – While services inflation declined by 0.2pp, goods inflation unexpectedly rose from 2.3% YY in April to 2.9% YY in May. This was largely driven by exchange-rate sensitive non-energy industrial goods (see Figure 1), where UK inflation is now 1.9pp higher above the Eurozone’s, suggesting a strong impact from sterling’s 18% depreciation since Nov-15.

BE11:12am

 May data could overstate the uptrend... – The rise in clothing inflation from 2.7% YY in April to 3.6% YY in May, its highest level since June 2013, might be driven by the exchange rate, but could also just reflect a different pattern of holidays or unusual sales seasons and may revert to more normal levels in the coming months.

BE11:12am

 .. but inflation uprevisions are ahead – During May, sterling traded about 3% higher on average than it does now, after the inconclusive election result. We estimate that this could lift the price level by and additional half a percent or so over the next three years, raising inflation by 0.1-0.2pp each year. We expect inflation to peak at 3.4% in 2Q 2018.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

 BoE unlikely to react to overshoot – The Bank of England’s 2.7% YY CPI forecast for 2Q looks too low (average 2.8% in April and May) as does its peak inflation forecast of 2.8% in 4Q-17. Sterling is about 3% lower than it was before the May Inflation Report. However, given the uncertain economic backdrop, we would not expect the Bank of England to consider giving hawkish signals at this point, unless the political uncertainty is resolved quickly. We stress that the rise in inflation further intensifies the squeeze on real wages, which are currently rising by hardly more than 2% YY

BE11:13am

And HSBC

BE11:13am

As recently as last October, the Bank of England was writing letters to the Treasury to explain why CPI inflation was running more than 1ppt below its 2.0% inflation target. With inflation currently at 2.9% and likely, we think, to climb a little above 3% later this year, the BoE will once again be writing letters.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

But those BoE letters are likely to say that the MPC will 'look through' the inflation target overshoot, as it is largely sterling-related and therefore temporary. Consistent with that view, a sizable chunk of May's increase in the inflation rate can be accounted for by import-intensive components of CPI, such as toys, food and household goods. And while overall goods inflation climbed from 2.3% to 2.9% y-o-y in May, more domestically-generated services inflation edged down from 2.8% to 2.7% y-o-y.
Tomorrow's labour market data might give us another indication of the softness of domestic inflationary pressure. Despite strength on the employment side of the labour market, average annual wage growth is barely running above 2% y-o-y -- around half its pre-crisis average rate. One risk, however, is that if EU migration falls back sharply as Brexit looms (there is already some evidence of this, according to the ONS's latest migration stats), wage pressures might start increasing in some sectors. The hung parliament outcome of last week's General Election injects more uncertainty into the inflation outlook. Our currency strategist have not changed their sterling forecasts (see our June currency outlook), the fragile political setup adds another layer of uncertainty for the currency, which will have implications for inflation. Political uncertainty might also have implications for domestic demand and inflationary pressure. For these reasons, the MPC has all the more reason to stand pat for now. Our forecast is for bank rate to remain unchanged at 0.25% for the whole of this year and next.

undefined
BE11:15am

And so, out of macro and into micro.

11:15 am
Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 617.00, up 66.5 (+12.08%), High: 634.50, Low: 595.00, Volume: 5.31m
BE11:15am

Cracking stuff this.

BE11:15am

Trading's no worse than previously indicated.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

IFRS15 is probably going to be okay, maybe, though with the unintended consequence of fudging all YOY comparisons.

BE11:16am

Its CEO hunt has moved from a longlist to a shortlist.

BE11:17am

CAS hasn't been sold yet, and there's still a 5.5% divi for the new person to scrap.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

As UBS says ....

BE11:17am

BE11:17am

"Making progress towards the first steps".

11:17 am
BE11:17am

I mean, in what universe is that an investment case?

BE11:18am

However, there's a 6% or thereabouts short in Capita and that's probably enough to explain today's rather enthusiastic response to what looks a lot like a holder statement.

BE11:18am

Here's Barclays.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Trading is said to be in line with expectations and guidance appears unchanged, although this is clouded by us not knowing the impact of IFRS15. The restructuring of the group is ongoing with the sale of Asset Services expected to complete in the second half. The statement takes a fairly positive view of both internal developments and the outlook for new work. Our view is Capita is not out of the woods yet, as further contract reviews cannot be ruled out, the pipeline is still weak and we see near-term re-rating as unlikely until there is a new CEO and a sense of stability. Capita trades on c10x FY18e (post disposal) PE with a c8% FY18e FCF yield.

BE11:18am

And RBC.

BE11:18am

The fact there is no real new negative news and that it appears IFRS15 will not be a major negative will probably be the focus for the market today. The stock still looks headline cheap (17E PE 11x, div yield 5.8%) but we remain at Sector Perform, believing risks remain high - the appointment of a credible new CEO and the sale of CAS are now be key catalysts for the business.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

And Morgan Stanley, to go a little deeper into the IFRS15 switcheroo Capita's just pulled.

BE11:20am

You'll note that while Capita's fine with 2017 there's a lack of guidance on revisions to periods already reported, by the way. I'm sure you'll have noted that.

BE11:20am

Here's MOST.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Trading is in line for the FY and 1H 2017 guidance arguably improved, but this is using IFRS 17 so it is not using comparable numbers, contract wins weaker, and pipeline flat. Note that trading is “in line with expectations” for the FY and “under IFRS 15, performance won’t be lower than market expectations”, while guidance for 1H has arguably improved to be “no lower” than 2H 2016 under IFRS 15 (this was below previously). But, this could mean that it includes some revenue and profit that it has recognised already under previous accounting periods (i.e. accrued income on the balance sheet, which can be written off vs reserves and then recognised according to more conservative IFRS 15). Other key points: 1) Contract wins are weak at £318m to June 13th compared to £458m to May 10th in 2016. 2) The pipeline is flat at £3.8bn (but no visibility on contents). 3) The spec rec business has been sold (no details) and CAS is on track to conclude in 2H. 4) Cost savings on track. 5) Trading in line: IT servs/Europe better and property/employee services/learnings services yet to improve. 6) NHS Primary care and DIO called out for higher cash costs/lower profits (DIO likely to re-tender in 2019). 6) it still expects “sustained and profitable growth in 2018”.

BE11:21am

To recap on why this is important ..............

BE11:21am

IFRS 15 enables the writing off of accrued income (i.e. revenue recognised but not billed) from the balance sheet through reserves (so no prior year adjustment to the P&L). This revenue can then be recognised effectively under IFRS 15 again as the customer takes control of the asset.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

.......... Which caused a lot of fun for Rolls Royce last year, and is currently causing some fun for the outsourcers. Who knows who's next?

undefined
BE11:23am

Elsewhere in trading updates .........

11:23 am
Merlin Entertainments PLC (MERL:LSE): Last: 489.70, down 13.3 (-2.64%), High: 493.40, Low: 482.50, Volume: 1.84m
BE11:23am

Precisely as expected, really, so the price response is a bit confusing.

BE11:24am

As in, trading's been reasonably strong.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

The bounceback from earlier in the year continued right up to the election, when a couple of well-publicised events happened that put off foreign visitors.

BE11:25am

And because there's a lag between events and bookings, that makes 2017 as a whole a bit difficult to call.

BE11:25am

How can this be a surprise to anyone! We wrote about 70% of the statement on here last week from the tops of our heads!

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Bah. Have some comment.

BE11:26am

Panmure.

BE11:27am

Trading YTD is broadly in-line with expectations, with management flagging some Midway London impact from elevated terrorism disruption, as expected. We feel Merlin warrants core holding status in the consumer space. In an environment of shaky domestic consumer sentiment, widespread geopolitical unrest, emerging cost inflation and volatile FX, Merlin’s diverse portfolio of brands/formats/geographies (greater than 70% profits ex-UK) offers resilient growth, playing to enduring structural trends (‘experiential’ leisure, hotels, prominence of IP, Asia). BUY, 525p TP.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Stifel.

BE11:28am

Midway Attractions (47% of EBITDA): Trading in the London attractions in the early part of the year benefited from increased foreign visitors. However there has been a significant reduction in domestic visitors following the recent terror attacks and Merlin is cautious on the outlook for the peak summer months in London. We estimate the London attractions represent around 30% of revenue for the division and a higher proportion of profit. The international operations appear to be performing in line with expectations. We reduce our like-for-like sales assumption for the division from 3.0% to 1.5%.

BE11:28am

LEGOLAND (39% of EBITDA): Trading has been in line with expectations although there has been some impact on the Windsor (UK) park in recent weeks following the terror attacks. The new LEGOLAND in Japan, which opened in April 2017, is trading in line with budget and we expect a small contribution net of pre-opening costs this year. Merlin appears to be making progress towards the opening of a new LEGOLAND in Goshen, New York State in a protracted planning process, despite some local opposition to the project. A final decision on planning consent for this park, which will cost $250m plus and will be fully funded by Merlin due to its favourable demographic profile, is expected in August. Our forecasts for the division, which assume like-for-like sales growth of 4.5% are unchanged.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Resort Theme Parks (14% of EBITDA): Trading has been in line with expectations although the UK parks have been affected in recent weeks by the terror attacks. While profits in 2017 may fall below earlier expectations, management remains confident that profitability will return to 2014 levels of £87m of EBITDA next year.

BE11:29am

Outlook: Trading has been broadly in line with expectations in the early months of the year. Good progress is being made towards the previously stated 2020 milestones in terms of the opening programme.

BE11:29am

Forecasts: We reduce our EBITDA and pre-tax profit forecasts by £15m to £475m and £280m respectively for 2017. The outlook is uncertain given the seasonality of the business and the high level of operational gearing, together with the recent escalation of attacks in the UK.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Valuation: This is a somewhat cautious update today. The shares have traded broadly in line with the FT All Share Index in the last quarter. While Merlin has attractive medium-term prospects, the rating of the shares at 24x prospective earnings for 2017 is demanding and offers little room for disappointment.

BE11:30am

Did you read the stuff we wrote up a month or two ago about Merlin expanding its hotels business for theme park sleepovers?

BE11:30am

Pricing is un-be-lievable.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

£450 a night for Legoland.

BE11:30am

https://www.ft.com...-9ec8-168383da43b7

BE11:31am

And to be clear, you have to pay them £450. They don't pay you.

11:31 am
undefined
BE11:32am

Monitise, ROTR? Sure.

BE11:32am

Thoguh there's not much we can do beyond note the statement.

11:32 am
Monitise PLC (MONI:LSE): Last: 2.82, up 0.52 (+22.61%), High: 2.88, Low: 2.82, Volume: 85.80m
BE11:32am

2.9p offer, cash. Valuing it at £70m.

BE11:33am

Fiserv is the buyer, an American company I know nothing about, but its name sounds very fintech.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Google FINkit for more on what they do.

BE11:34am

And no, apologies, I haven't had time to update that Monitise share count vs retained earnings graph.

BE11:35am

Here we are on the theme back in 2015. http://ftalphavill...tslive/2015-01-22/

11:35 am
undefined
BE11:36am

Were else then? There's some sellside we can nip through.

BE11:38am

I lost quite a lot of the morning to a Kepler note on luxury goods.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

204 pages of it.

BE11:38am

We initiate coverage on Kering and LVMH with a Buy rating, and Burberry, Hermes and Prada with a Hold rating.

BE11:38am

The working's extremely detailed, and not really captured by the six charts they use to sum up the argument.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

BE11:39am

BE11:39am

11:39 am
BE11:39am

BE11:39am

Chart three's an interesting one.

BE11:06am

TGIF, huh?

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Which leads to oddities like Chart 20:

BE11:40am

BE11:40am

That's the artistic director for Richemont's Chloe label, in case you're wondering.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Her sulphurous image can be seen on social media, and her trend-setting partner (Olivier Zahm, the magazine editor of Purple) makes for a particularly fashionable couple. This is a big departure from the upscale and wise image of the previous designer, Clare Waight Keller.

BE11:40am

Sulphurous!

BE11:40am

There's also quite a lot about online branding.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

BE11:41am

.... and how the brands can make use of those stark, minimalist, intimidating stores on Bond Street as places where people return the stuff they've bought online.

BE11:41am

Because return rates are insane!

11:41 am
BE11:41am

L2 research shows that allowing clients to collect their internet purchases or return items to the store can be highly beneficial. According to L2, the average rate of return in dollar terms is c. 23%, which means that for every USD100m of sales, only USD77 become net sales. For some online-only retailers, such as Yoox, this rate stood at 28%, while for Net-a-Porter the return rate is even higher (KECH forecast: 40%).

BE11:41am

Imagine running a business where four out of every ten things you sell get returned.

BE11:42am

What do you do with all that stuff? Give it some Febreeze, bag it up again and resale? Or cut the labels off and give it to TK Maxx?

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Anyway, more important from an investment perspective is an exhaustive analysis of consolidation targets, in which Burberry's the only one whose bid likelihood rates "high"

BE11:42am

BE11:43am

(Right click and open new window to make legible.)

11:42 am
BE11:43am

........ And a list of consolidators, of which Richemont is top of the pile.

BE11:43am

BE11:43am

....... Which comes with the caveat that luxury M&A has been value destructive. Like, spectacularly.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

KLF levels of value destruction.

BE11:43am

Swatch is the only one that's done it right.

BE11:43am

11:43 am
BE11:43am

(Watches, arguably, offer a bunch of synergies that frocks don't.)

BE11:44am

Anyway!

BE11:44am

Let me spin forward to the Burberry bit, since that's our remit here.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

At least a year in the wilderness while Bailey gets locked in an office and forgotten about, says Kepler.

BE11:44am

Burberry’s top management and creative teams are changing. Marco Gobbetti (former CEO of Celine, LVMH) will take up the CEO position in July, bringing along his luxury brand turnaround expertise. Christopher Bailey will then take the newly created role of Burberry’s president and chief creative officer. While we believe these changes and some hires on the creative team could help generate growth and value, the impact on collections and trading might not be visible until 2018.

BE11:45am

Our TP of 1,740p is derived from the average of a DCF model and a peer comparison. Most of the companies in the sector report strong growth and recovering margins, while Burberry will continue to lag for several quarters, in our view. On a three-year perspective, however, if new management is successful and the brand is fairly repositioned, Burberry shares could rerate.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

While we think Marco Gobbetti will be successful, we see the transition period and the execution of the cost-saving plan as the main risks for the company: pre-Gobbetti collections and a tough comparison base could lead to disappointment. On the other hand, Burberry’s recent changes make it a candidate for a potential takeover bid, especially on the back of GBL’s taking a 3% stake in the company. This could put our Hold rating at risk.

undefined
BE11:46am

Elsewhere in sellside, there's MOST on 3i.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

The discount non-food retailer disguised as a private equity fund.

BE11:48am

You'll remember Geoff Ruddell of Morgan Stanley did some very good work on Action, the retail bit of 3i. He's co-author here.

BE11:48am

Robust earnings delivery and unrealised PE portfolio valuation
gains drive NAV uplift. We value Action at 341p per 3i share
with increased confidence on delivery. While 3i's remaining PE
portfolio provides upside earnings risk, we see better risk
reward elsewhere in the asset management space.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Increasing Price Target to 940p. Strong earnings growth and higher unrealised value gains at Action and Scandlines drive lift in 2018e NAV to 662p. Post ~36% RoE in FY17, 3i's PE assets' earnings performance should remain strong - we see ~17% value weighted earnings growth in FY18e (6% PE portfolio earnings growth ex. Action). We forecast ~£750m of new investments to Mar'18 with ~€400m of investments already executed YTD. Unrealised PE portfolio gains with strong earnings performance support ~14% average RoE for the next 3 years.

BE11:48am

Adjusting our Action valuation. Post CMD, we are more confident in Action's ability to deliver on our projection of 200 new stores pa. Management remains focused on profitable growth with the surprise element helping to drive traffic and market penetration. More so, Action's SKU concentration coupled with higher sales is driving Action's buying power with suppliers helping to further reinforce Action's price advantage. We adjust our DCF assumptions and eliminate the haircut in our valuation of 3i's Action stake but retain a 5% liquidity discount given Action is unlisted, taking Action's valuation to 341p per 3i share (prev 279p).

BE11:49am

Taking profits. After strong price performance and given limited upside, we see better risk reward elsewhere. 3i's valuation of ~1.42x 2018e NAV, looks more reasonable at 1.15x after adjusting for Action's DCF. More so, our FY18 earnings growth forecast for 3i's PE portfolio ex-Action of 6% vs ~12% estimated in FY17 suggests upside risk to earnings. A 1% increase in earnings and 0.5x multiple change would lift our FY18e NAV and price target by 1%.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

What would change our view? Better than expected performance from Action or we gain confidence in its capacity to deliver greater than 200 new stores pa. 3i's ability to sustainably deliver above 2x cash-to-cash multiple on PE investments could warrant a lift in NAV valuation multiple (1.25x in our base case). On the downside, (i) a significant deterioration in Action's performance or shortfall in new store openings vs. our projections; (ii) lower earnings growth from the rest of 3i's portfolio assets or weak market sentiment leading to lower valuation multiple.

BE11:50am

@wayneJ: an FT premium subscription is a luxury good. It is inspirational and aspirational.

BE11:51am

@wayneJ: the regular FT subscription is like Miu Miu to Prada, or Cheap & Chic to Moschino.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

And you folks over there on free logins are Primark.

undefined
BE11:52am

Oh, I forgot to do a 3i price.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

iii:LSE

BE11:53am

.... because it never works! It's down 2.9% at 901.5p anyway.

BE11:54am

ROTR: I think the "KLF return" thing wasn't entirely true, or at least deliberately vague.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We'll only know after Bill and Jimmy actually do it, which is their style.

BE11:55am

Okay, back to the remit. Someone was nagging for Iomart earlier.

iomart group PLC (IOM:LSE): Last: 325.25, down 13.75 (-4.06%), High: 342.00, Low: 320.00, Volume: 1.39m
11:55 am
BE11:56am

Nothing much wrong with the numbers, according to FinnCapppp (which is house broker)

BE11:56am

Prelims are in line with unchanged expectations for the year ending March 2017, with cash generation ahead, again
demonstrating the quality of the business. 11% growth in cloud services revenue was supported by organic revenue
growth of 10%; while Easyspace, which suffered organic revenue decline in FY16 (-8%), returned to organic growth (+4%),
added to by United Hosting (acquired November 2015) to deliver 22% overall growth. As ever, therefore, the typical iomart
steady pace of bolt-on acquisitions added to group performance, with 17% headline growth, EBITDA margin of 40.8%, and
free cash flow of £19.3m. With such strong levels of cash, visibility and confidence, the board has accelerated the
expected dividend growth one year ahead of our expectations, lifting the full-year dividend to 6.0p (+88% vs FY16; +18%
vs FY17E), while still retaining a strong balance sheet to fund further strategic acquisitions. The quality of the company
remains difficult to match, with expected results routinely delivered with a maximum variation of 1-2% before acquisitions.
Target lifted to 400p (360p)

BE11:56am

Revenue
of £89.2m delivered adjusted PBT of £22.4m, in line with
expectations. £19.3m free cash flow exceeded our £17.9m forecast, leading to
net debt of £10.6m vs £12.5mE. The acceleration in dividend growth from 3.2p
was expected; however, 6.0p beat our expectations of 5.1p and highlights
board confidence in the business's combination of growth, profitability, and
cash generation, while not jeopardising capacity for further acquisitions.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Now operating as three divisions, namely cloud services, Easyspace, and
non recurring revenue (principally Cristie, the storage-based business with
public sector customer relationships during the storage tech refresh cycle),
each displays differing gross margin and EBITDA characteristics, evident in the
changing group mix, while adjusted PBT margin is maintained – and remains
highest in the peer group. Recurring revenue is over 90%, adjusted PBT
margin 25%, and FCF per share is expected to exceed adj dil. EPS in FY19 –
yet FY19 free cash flow yield of 6.5% shows quality is evident but market
appreciation is not. We lift our target to 400p, still meek due to current market
wariness of the sector, with iomart harbouring plenty more upside when peers’
woes are more distant history

BE11:58am

Peel Hunt too. Also house. "Marketing communication" disclaimer prominently on the blue space, next to the buy rec.

BE11:58am

iomart reported a good set of results where revenue and profits
for FY17A were in line, and accounting for some movements
(Dediserve acquisition, softer SystemsUp, better EasySpace
traction, etc), our revenue and profit forecasts are largely
unchanged over the next two years. Impressively, FY17A free
cash flow was up 73% yoy, on the back of which we upgrade our
FY16-19E FCF CAGR from 21% to 24%. Therefore, we
confidently reiterate our Buy recommendation on iomart, noting
that it is : (1) a pick-and-shovels play on multi-cloud take-up;
(2) a model that lends itself to strong FCF growth; and
(3) an attractive valuation vs peers, given its role in the world of
Cloud.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Results and forecasts changes. The FY17A results were in line with the end-March trading update. A slight 2% beat at the adj diluted EPS level was due to lower tax expense. Better working capital management and controlled capex spend led to a FCF of £20.5m, ahead of our £16.6m forecast. The company has delivered a 35% pay-out, a dividend of 6p, for FY17A. Trading since the year-end has been broadly in line. Taking account of a more muted outlook for public cloud consultancy SystemsUp, and incorporating the recent Dediserve acquisition, we leave our forecasts unchanged at the revenue and adj EBITDA level. Changes to D&A, tax rate, etc leads us to fine tune our adj dil EPS forecast for FY18E (-3%) and FY19E (+5%).

BE11:59am

On track to meet its three-year plan. iomart’s track-record is one of well managed growth (both organic and inorganic), margins and cash conversion. Back in March-2015, the company set a three-year target to March-2018 where it plans to hit £100m of revenue (PHe £98m), an adj EBITDA margin of 40% (PHe 40.5%) and an adj PBT of 25% (PHe 25.1%). As our forecasts imply, the company is well on-track to meet these targets, a fact we believe is under-appreciated.

BE11:59am

iomart is at a sweet spot. IT is not just about buying Amazon AWS, deploying Docker containers, or implementing virtual execution technology against cybersecurity threats. Much of enterprise IT that we will use tomorrow is already in place, and what many organisations seek is for a partner who has an established track record, necessary accreditations and the required infrastructure, to hold their hand in the journey that is the Cloud. This, in our view, is iomart’s sweet spot. We believe that around 80% of the emerging Cloud opportunities will be of a hybrid-nature. Hypercloud vendors like Microsoft have recognised this fact, and are very supportive of partners like iomart. We believe this emerging multi-cloud world (see 31 March 2017 note) is a place where iomart will thrive.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Valuation. On consensus numbers, iomart trades on 9.1x CY18 EV/EBITDA, broadly in line with Hosting and IT Services Peers on c8.5-9x. Is it, however, at a deep discount to Colocation Peers on 16.2x. We reiterate our Buy rating with an updated DCF derived target price of 388p, at which iomart will trade on a CY18 EV/EBITDA of 10.2x, a slightly reduced discount to Colo Peers.

undefined
BE12:01pm

ROTR, did we ever get an answer as to what Stanley Gibbons owns in freehold and long leases?

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

I've not had time to go through the books properly, because I've been reading 200-page Kepler notes on luxury goods.

BE12:02pm

It still has that big shop on 399 Strand, doesn't it?

BE12:03pm

What's the ownership status of that?

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Oh, and speaking of iconic names with overly expensive offices in landmark locations ......

London Stock Exchange Group PLC (LSE:LSE): Last: 3,549, up 150 (+4.41%), High: 3,560, Low: 3,403, Volume: 658.43k
BE12:04pm

Lots of positive comment on the back of yesterday's investor day.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Here's RBC.

BE12:05pm

The Investor Update provided a credible path, including the
recent acquisition (which is 4%-5% accretive but not included in our forecasts because of vague deal closure timing), to 200p in basic EPS in 2019E. Price target increased 6% to 3800p; Outperform rating reiterated.

BE12:06pm

Yesterday LSEG provided 76 pages of additional detail on its growth opportunities and efficiency plans. We are confident in our forecasts, regardless of market conditions and regardless of the regulatory environment, mostly because it is our opinion that LSEG is exposed to structural growth drivers, such as mandatory central clearing and increased demand for benchmarks, analytics and data solutions. Our revised forecasts call for EPS and dividend CAGRs (2016A-19E) of +16% and +21%, respectively. We reiterate our Outperform rating based upon strong growth metrics with further optionality around balance sheet deployment, both for inorganic initiatives and shareholder returns.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

And BNP.

BE12:06pm

LSE’s new 55% EBITDA targets were not taken so well by the markets despite them implying 18% EBITDA CAGR 16-19E, and 15% upside to consensus earnings. We believe that there is some caution exercised by the market in relation to these targets as they rely on a step-up in group revenue growth to ~11% CAGR 16-19E to offset further investment in the cost base (4% pa over the next three years). We estimate that LSE is targeting 15% revenue growth at LCH and in indices to achieve this, which requires an acceleration in growth.

BE12:07pm

We continue to like the potential value creation from LSE doing deals and see scope for further bolt-ons (~GBP600m of firepower for cash deals). We also see large transformational deals remaining on the table: LSE is looking at opportunities in global custody and discussed bolt-on opportunities in all areas of businesses. Finally, Mr Rolet confirmed his view on the scope for further global deals in the long term. We see a deal between ICE or CME and LSE as feasible from both a political and competition standpoint.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

While LSE trades at c.22x P/E 17E, the highest among European exchanges, we still believe that the stock offers the most attractive risk/reward, given its superior growth and M&A optionality. Our TP remains unchanged, as part of the increase in EPS is linked to debt-financed M&A.

BE12:07pm

And Credit Suisse.

BE12:08pm

Raising EPS estimates & target price: We have upgraded our 2018/19 EPS estimates 2-3% mainly reflecting the share buyback and recent acquisitions (The Yield Book & Citi Fixed Income Indexes). We increase our target price from 3100p to 3600p reflecting our revised EPS estimates and increased medium term EBT growth forecast in our three stage DCF model (7% CAGR 2020-22 vs. 6% previously) driven by our increased confidence in the longer-term growth prospects for the index/OTC clearing businesses.
